metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Calculations related to the application of stoichiometry to reactions involving the combustion of fuels, including mass-mass, mass-volume and volume-volume stoichiometry, to determine heat energy released, reactant and product amounts and net volume or mass of major greenhouse gases (CO₂, CH₄ and H₂O), limited to standard laboratory conditions (SLC) at 25 °C and 100 kPa

stoichiometry_definition.name: Stoichiometry Definition
stoichiometry_definition.correct: Stoichiometry is the quantitative relationship between reactants and products in a chemical reaction, based on the mole ratios from the balanced equation.

the mass of reactants only.error: Stoichiometry involves both reactants AND products, not just reactants.
the mass of reactants only.fix: Stoichiometry relates amounts of any substances in a reaction using mole ratios.
the mass of reactants only.action: Look at a balanced equation. Coefficients give ratios for ALL species.

the speed of a reaction.fix: Stoichiometry is about AMOUNTS. Rate is about how FAST reactions occur.
the speed of a reaction.action: Stoichiometry = how much. Kinetics = how fast. Different concepts.

the energy of a reaction.error: That's thermochemistry. Stoichiometry is about amounts.
the energy of a reaction.fix: Stoichiometry calculates moles, masses, volumes. Energy needs enthalpy values.
the energy of a reaction.action: You can USE stoichiometry to find energy, but stoichiometry itself is about quantities.

persistent.gap: You're confusing stoichiometry with other aspects of reactions.
persistent.action: Define clearly: stoichiometry = quantitative relationships from coefficients in balanced equations.

mole_ratio.name: Mole Ratio from Coefficients
mole_ratio.correct: The coefficients in a balanced equation give the mole ratio between all species. For CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O, the ratio is 1:2:1:2.

mass ratio.error: Coefficients give MOLE ratios, not mass ratios.
mass ratio.fix: Equal coefficients mean equal moles, not equal masses. 1 mol CH₄ ≠ 1 mol CO₂ by mass.
mass ratio.action: Convert to moles first, then use coefficients, then convert back to mass if needed.

volume ratio for all states.error: Volume ratios only work for gases at same conditions.
volume ratio for all states.fix: Coefficients directly give volume ratios only for gases. Liquids and solids need different treatment.
volume ratio for all states.action: Check states: (g) to (g) can use volume ratios. Mixed states need mole conversions.

atomic ratio.error: Coefficients give molecular/formula unit ratios, not individual atom ratios.
atomic ratio.fix: The coefficient applies to the whole formula unit, not individual atoms.
atomic ratio.action: 2H₂O means 2 molecules of H₂O, not 2 hydrogen atoms.

persistent.gap: You're misinterpreting what equation coefficients represent.
persistent.action: Practice: write mole ratios from 10 different balanced equations.

slc_conditions.name: Standard Laboratory Conditions
slc_conditions.correct: Standard laboratory conditions (SLC) are 25°C and 100 kPa. At SLC, the molar volume of any ideal gas is 24.8 L mol⁻¹.

0°C and 101.3 kPa.error: That's STP (Standard Temperature and Pressure), not SLC.
0°C and 101.3 kPa.fix: SLC = 25°C, 100 kPa. STP = 0°C, 101.3 kPa. VCE Chemistry uses SLC.
0°C and 101.3 kPa.action: Memorise: SLC = room temperature (25°C) and 100 kPa. Molar volume = 24.8 L.

20°C and 100 kPa.error: Close, but SLC is specifically 25°C, not 20°C.
20°C and 100 kPa.fix: SLC temperature is 25°C (298 K), which gives molar volume of 24.8 L mol⁻¹.
20°C and 100 kPa.action: Remember: 25°C is the standard, giving Vm = 24.8 L mol⁻¹.

25°C and 101.3 kPa.error: SLC pressure is 100 kPa exactly, not 101.3 kPa.
25°C and 101.3 kPa.fix: SLC uses exactly 100 kPa (1 bar), making calculations simpler.
25°C and 101.3 kPa.action: 100 kPa is the IUPAC standard. 101.3 kPa is atmospheric pressure.

persistent.gap: You're confusing SLC with STP or other standard conditions.
persistent.action: Make a flashcard: SLC = 25°C + 100 kPa + 24.8 L mol⁻¹.

molar_volume.name: Molar Volume at SLC
molar_volume.correct: At SLC, one mole of any ideal gas occupies 24.8 L. This allows conversion between moles and volume: n = V/Vm.

22.4 L mol⁻¹.error: 22.4 L mol⁻¹ is the molar volume at STP, not SLC.
22.4 L mol⁻¹.fix: At SLC (25°C), gases expand more than at STP (0°C), so Vm is larger.
22.4 L mol⁻¹.action: SLC is warmer than STP, so gases take up more space: 24.8 L vs 22.4 L.

24.8 mL mol⁻¹.error: Wrong unit. Molar volume is in LITRES, not millilitres.
24.8 mL mol⁻¹.fix: 24.8 L mol⁻¹ means one mole occupies 24,800 mL, not 24.8 mL.
24.8 mL mol⁻¹.action: Always check units. L and mL differ by factor of 1000.

it varies for different gases.error: At the same conditions, all ideal gases have the same molar volume.
it varies for different gases.fix: Avogadro's law: equal volumes of gases at same T and P contain equal moles.
it varies for different gases.action: 1 mol of H₂, O₂, CO₂ all occupy 24.8 L at SLC.

persistent.gap: You're not clear on what molar volume means or its value at SLC.
persistent.action: Practice: calculate volumes for different mole amounts using Vm = 24.8 L mol⁻¹.

mass_to_moles.name: Mass to Moles Conversion
mass_to_moles.correct: To convert mass to moles, divide mass by molar mass: n = m/M. Units: grams ÷ (grams per mole) = moles.

n = M/m.error: Inverted. You've put M on top instead of m.
n = M/m.fix: n = m/M. Mass divided by molar mass gives moles.
n = M/m.action: Think units: g ÷ (g/mol) = mol. Mass must be on top.

n = m × M.error: Multiplication gives wrong units. You need division.
n = m × M.fix: g × (g/mol) doesn't give moles. You need g ÷ (g/mol) = mol.
n = m × M.action: Check units: n should be in mol. Only division gives correct units.

n = m + M.error: Addition makes no sense here. You can't add mass and molar mass.
n = m + M.fix: The formula is n = m/M (division), not addition.
n = m + M.action: Formulas involve operations that make dimensional sense.

persistent.gap: You're not remembering the correct formula structure.
persistent.action: Write n = m/M 20 times, then solve 10 practice problems.

moles_to_volume.name: Moles to Volume Conversion
moles_to_volume.formula: V = n × Vm or n = V/Vm
moles_to_volume.correct: For gases at SLC: V = n × Vm gives volume in litres. Rearranged: n = V/Vm.

V = n/Vm.error: Inverted. Division would give wrong units.
V = n/Vm.fix: V = n × Vm. mol × (L/mol) = L. Multiplication cancels mol.
V = n/Vm.action: Check: mol × (L/mol) = L. Division would give mol²/L.

V = m × Vm.error: You need moles (n), not mass (m), to use molar volume.
V = m × Vm.fix: First convert mass to moles (n = m/M), then use V = n × Vm.
V = m × Vm.action: Mass-volume is two steps: mass → moles → volume.

V = Vm/n.error: This would give larger volume for fewer moles, which is backwards.
V = Vm/n.fix: More moles = more volume. V = n × Vm shows this direct relationship.
V = Vm/n.action: Double the moles should double the volume. Test your formula.

persistent.gap: You're confusing multiplication and division in gas calculations.
persistent.action: Derive from units: n (mol) × Vm (L/mol) = V (L). The mol cancels.

mass_mass_process.name: Mass-Mass Stoichiometry Process
mass_mass_process.correct: Mass-mass stoichiometry: (1) convert known mass to moles, (2) use mole ratio from equation, (3) convert unknown moles to mass.

directly multiply masses by ratio.error: You cannot use mass ratios directly. Coefficients give MOLE ratios.
directly multiply masses by ratio.fix: Masses of different substances are not in the same ratio as moles.
directly multiply masses by ratio.action: Example: 1 mol CH₄ (16 g) produces 1 mol CO₂ (44 g). Not 1:1 by mass.

convert mass to volume first.error: Mass-mass doesn't involve volume at all.
convert mass to volume first.fix: Mass-mass: mass → moles → ratio → moles → mass. No volume step.
convert mass to volume first.action: Only use volume for gases. Solids and liquids use mass throughout.

use coefficients as mass multipliers.fix: You must convert to moles first, then apply the coefficient ratio.
use coefficients as mass multipliers.action: Step-by-step: m → n (using M), then n × ratio, then n → m (using M).

persistent.gap: You're trying to skip the mole conversion step.
persistent.action: Always show: n = m/M, then ratio, then m = n × M. Never skip steps.

mass_volume_process.name: Mass-Volume Stoichiometry Process
mass_volume_process.formula: mass → moles → ratio → moles → volume (or reverse)
mass_volume_process.correct: Mass-volume stoichiometry connects mass of one substance to volume of a gas: convert mass to moles, apply ratio, convert moles to volume using Vm.

mass divided by molar volume directly.error: You can't divide mass by molar volume. Units don't work.
mass divided by molar volume directly.fix: Mass must first become moles (÷M), then moles become volume (×Vm).
mass divided by molar volume directly.action: g ÷ (L/mol) doesn't give sensible units. Need g ÷ (g/mol) first.

skip the mole ratio step.error: You must apply the stoichiometric ratio between substances.
skip the mole ratio step.fix: The mole ratio from coefficients links the two different substances.
skip the mole ratio step.action: If 1 mol propane makes 3 mol CO₂, you need that ×3 step.

use 22.4 L mol⁻¹.error: 22.4 L mol⁻¹ is for STP, not SLC. VCE uses SLC.
use 22.4 L mol⁻¹.fix: At SLC (25°C, 100 kPa), use Vm = 24.8 L mol⁻¹.
use 22.4 L mol⁻¹.action: Always check conditions. VCE Chemistry = SLC = 24.8 L mol⁻¹.

persistent.gap: You're not following the systematic conversion pathway.
persistent.action: Draw the pathway: mass → n (÷M) → ratio → n → V (×Vm). Follow it every time.

volume_volume_conditions.name: Volume-Volume Stoichiometry Conditions
volume_volume_conditions.formula: Only for gases at same T and P in closed system
volume_volume_conditions.correct: Volume-volume stoichiometry only works when: all species are gases, temperature is constant, pressure is constant, and the system is closed.

works for any substances.error: Volume ratios only equal mole ratios for gases.
works for any substances.fix: Liquids and solids don't follow Avogadro's law. Only gases do.
works for any substances.action: Check states: (g):(g) can use volume ratios. (s) or (l) cannot.

works at any temperature and pressure.error: T and P must be constant for the ratio to hold.
works at any temperature and pressure.fix: Avogadro's law applies at constant T and P. Changing conditions changes volumes.
works at any temperature and pressure.action: The ratio V₁:V₂ = n₁:n₂ only holds when T and P are the same for both.

works in open systems.error: Open systems can lose gases, breaking the relationship.
works in open systems.fix: A closed system keeps all gases contained so ratios are maintained.
works in open systems.action: If gas escapes, you can't track volumes properly.

persistent.gap: You're not checking the conditions for volume-volume calculations.
persistent.action: Checklist before using V:V ratios: (1) all gases? (2) constant T? (3) constant P? (4) closed system?

volume_volume_shortcut.name: Volume-Volume Direct Ratio
volume_volume_shortcut.correct: For gases at the same conditions, volume ratios equal mole ratios. You can use coefficients directly as volume multipliers without converting to moles.

volume ratios equal mass ratios.error: No. Volume ratios equal MOLE ratios for gases.
volume ratios equal mass ratios.fix: 1 L of O₂ and 1 L of H₂ have the same moles but different masses.
volume ratios equal mass ratios.action: Avogadro: equal volumes = equal moles (at same T, P). Not equal masses.

must convert to moles first.error: That's the long way. Volume-volume is a shortcut.
must convert to moles first.fix: Since V ∝ n for gases, and coefficients give n ratios, coefficients give V ratios directly.
must convert to moles first.action: If equation shows 1:3 mole ratio, it's also 1:3 volume ratio for gases.

multiply volume by molar mass.error: That would give mass, not the product volume.
multiply volume by molar mass.fix: For gases, just multiply by the coefficient ratio.
multiply volume by molar mass.action: 2 L CH₄ → 2 L CO₂ (1:1 ratio). No molar mass needed.

persistent.action: Practice: use coefficient ratios directly for 10 gas-only problems.

greenhouse_gases.name: Greenhouse Gas Products
greenhouse_gases.correct: Combustion of hydrocarbons produces the greenhouse gases CO₂ and H₂O. Incomplete combustion can also produce CO. CH₄ itself is a greenhouse gas.

only CO₂ is a greenhouse gas.error: H₂O and CH₄ are also significant greenhouse gases.
only CO₂ is a greenhouse gas.fix: Water vapour is the most abundant greenhouse gas. CH₄ is 80× more potent than CO₂.
only CO₂ is a greenhouse gas.action: All three (CO₂, H₂O, CH₄) trap infrared radiation and contribute to warming.

oxygen is a greenhouse gas.error: O₂ is not a greenhouse gas. It doesn't absorb infrared radiation.
oxygen is a greenhouse gas.fix: Greenhouse gases have molecular structures that absorb IR. O₂ doesn't.
oxygen is a greenhouse gas.action: Greenhouse gases: CO₂, H₂O, CH₄, N₂O. Not: O₂, N₂.

nitrogen is a greenhouse gas.error: N₂ is not a greenhouse gas (though N₂O is).
nitrogen is a greenhouse gas.fix: N₂ doesn't absorb infrared. N₂O (nitrous oxide) does but isn't from combustion.
nitrogen is a greenhouse gas.action: Combustion of hydrocarbons produces CO₂ and H₂O, not N₂O.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly identifying which products are greenhouse gases.
persistent.action: List combustion products (CO₂, H₂O, CO) and identify which are greenhouse gases.

limiting_reactant.name: Limiting Reactant Identification
limiting_reactant.correct: The limiting reactant is consumed first and determines product amount. Compare moles divided by coefficients; the smallest value indicates the limiting reactant.

the one with smaller mass.error: Mass doesn't determine limiting. You must compare MOLES relative to stoichiometry.
the one with smaller mass.fix: A small mass of a light substance might still be in excess.
the one with smaller mass.action: Convert masses to moles, then compare n/coefficient for each reactant.

the one with larger coefficient.error: Large coefficient means more is NEEDED, not that it's limiting.
the one with larger coefficient.fix: Limiting depends on what you HAVE vs what you NEED (the ratio).
the one with larger coefficient.action: Divide moles by coefficient. Smallest result = limiting reactant.

always the fuel.error: Either reactant could be limiting depending on amounts present.
always the fuel.fix: In excess air, fuel is limiting. In limited air, oxygen is limiting.

persistent.gap: You're not using the correct method to identify limiting reactants.
persistent.action: For each reactant: calculate n, divide by coefficient. Smallest = limiting.

energy_from_stoichiometry.name: Energy Calculations Using Stoichiometry
energy_from_stoichiometry.correct: Energy released = moles of fuel × molar enthalpy of combustion. Use stoichiometry to find moles, then multiply by ΔH.

Energy = mass × ΔH.error: ΔH is in kJ mol⁻¹, so you need moles, not mass.
Energy = mass × ΔH.fix: First convert mass to moles, then multiply by ΔH.
Energy = mass × ΔH.action: Units check: mol × (kJ/mol) = kJ. g × (kJ/mol) doesn't work.

Energy = volume × ΔH.error: You need moles, not volume directly.
Energy = volume × ΔH.fix: Convert volume to moles first (n = V/Vm), then multiply by ΔH.
Energy = volume × ΔH.action: For gases: V → n → Energy. Don't skip the mole step.

Energy equals the coefficient.error: The coefficient gives mole ratios, not energy values.
Energy equals the coefficient.fix: You need the actual ΔH value from data tables.
Energy equals the coefficient.action: Coefficients tell you HOW MUCH reacts. ΔH tells you energy per mole.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting stoichiometry to energy calculations correctly.
persistent.action: Pathway: mass/volume → moles → Energy using E = n × ΔH.

d3.tooltip: Coefficients represent numbers of formula units

d4.tooltip: Different substances have different molar masses

mass_volume.instructions: Complete the statements about mass-volume calculations.

sentences.text: Mass-volume stoichiometry connects the mass of one substance to the {{d1}} of a gaseous substance at {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: We're relating mass to volume of a gas

d2.tooltip: VCE Chemistry uses standard laboratory conditions

sentences.text: To convert moles of gas to volume at SLC, use {{d3}}, which gives volume in {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Moles multiplied by molar volume at SLC

sentences.text: The process for mass-volume calculations is: convert mass to {{d5}}, apply the stoichiometric {{d6}}, then convert to volume.
To find the volume of CO₂ produced from burning propane, you need the {{d7}} of propane and the {{d8}} at SLC.

d7.tooltip: Needed to convert mass to moles

d8.tooltip: Needed to convert moles to volume

sentences.text: Volume-volume stoichiometry only applies when all substances involved are {{d1}} at the same {{d2}} and pressure.

sentences.text: For gases at the same conditions, the volume ratio equals the {{d3}} ratio, which equals the {{d4}} from the balanced equation.

d3.tooltip: Avogadro's law: equal volumes = equal moles

d4.tooltip: The numbers in front of formulas

sentences.text: For CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(g), if 5 L of methane burns, it produces {{d5}} L of CO₂ and {{d6}} L of water vapour.
The volume-volume shortcut avoids converting to {{d7}} because volume ratios directly equal {{d8}} ratios for gases.

fundamentals.instructions: Apply your understanding of stoichiometry to these scenarios.

sentences.text: When solving any stoichiometry problem, the central quantity you convert through is always {{d1}}, because equation coefficients give {{d2}} ratios.

d2.tooltip: Coefficients tell us about amounts in moles

sentences.text: A student calculates using 22.4 L mol⁻¹ for molar volume. This is {{d3}} because that value applies to {{d4}}, not SLC.
The molar volume at SLC (24.8 L mol⁻¹) is larger than at STP (22.4 L mol⁻¹) because SLC has a {{d5}} temperature, causing gases to {{d6}}.

mass_mass.title: Mass-Mass Problem Solving
mass_mass.instructions: Apply mass-mass stoichiometry to solve problems.

sentences.text: When 4.4 g of propane (M = 44 g mol⁻¹) burns, the moles of propane is {{d1}} mol, calculated by dividing mass by {{d2}}.
Using C₃H₈ + 5O₂ → 3CO₂ + 4H₂O, 0.10 mol propane produces {{d3}} mol of CO₂ because the ratio is {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: Coefficient of C₃H₈ is 1, CO₂ is 3

sentences.text: The mass of CO₂ produced from 0.30 mol is {{d5}} g, using the molar mass of CO₂ which is {{d6}} g mol⁻¹.
CO₂ and H₂O are both {{d7}} gases produced in combustion reactions. Calculating their masses helps assess {{d8}} impact.

mass_volume.title: Mass-Volume Problem Solving
mass_volume.instructions: Apply mass-volume stoichiometry to solve problems.

sentences.text: When 20.0 mL of butane (C₄H₁₀) burns at SLC, first convert volume to moles using n = V/Vm = 0.0200/{{d1}} = {{d2}} mol.

d1.tooltip: Molar volume at SLC in L mol⁻¹

sentences.text: For 2C₄H₁₀ + 13O₂ → 8CO₂ + 10H₂O, the mole ratio of butane to water is {{d3}}, so 8.06 × 10⁻⁴ mol butane produces {{d4}} mol water.

d3.tooltip: Compare coefficients of C₄H₁₀ and H₂O

sentences.text: To find the mass of water produced, multiply moles by molar mass: m = 4.03 × 10⁻³ × {{d5}} = {{d6}} g.
Mass-volume stoichiometry is useful for calculating volumes of {{d7}} products from known masses of {{d8}} or solid fuels.

d7.tooltip: Volume calculations mainly apply to gases

d8.tooltip: Fuels like petrol start as liquids

volume_volume.title: Volume-Volume Problem Solving
volume_volume.instructions: Apply volume-volume stoichiometry to solve problems.

sentences.text: Volume-volume stoichiometry is the simplest type because you can use {{d1}} directly as volume multipliers, without converting to {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: The numbers in the balanced equation

d2.tooltip: The middle conversion can be skipped

sentences.text: For the reaction 2H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2H₂O(g), burning 10 L of hydrogen requires {{d3}} L of oxygen and produces {{d4}} L of water vapour.
A closed reactor is essential for volume-volume stoichiometry because an {{d5}} system would allow gases to {{d6}}, breaking the volume relationship.

d6.tooltip: Gases leaving would change measured volumes

sentences.text: If products include water as a {{d7}}, the volume ratio only applies to the {{d8}} products, not liquid water.

d8.tooltip: Volume ratios only work for gases

fundamentals.title: Mastering Stoichiometry Concepts
fundamentals.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by addressing common errors and misconceptions.

sentences.text: A common error is using mass ratios instead of mole ratios. This fails because different substances have different {{d1}}, so equal moles have {{d2}} masses.

d1.tooltip: The mass of one mole varies by substance

d2.tooltip: 1 mol CH₄ ≠ 1 mol CO₂ by mass

sentences.text: Students sometimes confuse SLC with STP. At SLC, the temperature is {{d3}} than STP, resulting in a {{d4}} molar volume.

d4.tooltip: Higher T → more expansion → larger volume

sentences.text: The formula n = m/M can be rearranged to m = {{d5}} and M = {{d6}}, depending on what quantity you need to find.
To connect stoichiometry to energy, first find moles of fuel, then multiply by the {{d7}} of combustion to get total {{d8}} released.

mass_mass.title: Advanced Mass-Mass Applications
mass_mass.instructions: Apply advanced understanding of mass-mass stoichiometry.

sentences.text: When reactant amounts are given for both reactants, you must determine the {{d1}} reactant, which is the one that runs out {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: It limits the amount of product formed

d2.tooltip: The first to be completely consumed

sentences.text: To identify the limiting reactant, divide each reactant's moles by its {{d3}} and compare. The {{d4}} value indicates the limiting reactant.

d3.tooltip: The number in the balanced equation

sentences.text: In the complete combustion of octane (C₈H₁₈), the products are {{d5}} and {{d6}}, both of which contribute to the greenhouse effect.
If incomplete combustion occurs due to insufficient oxygen, {{d7}} is produced instead of CO₂, and less {{d8}} is released per mole of fuel.

mass_volume.title: Advanced Mass-Volume Applications
mass_volume.instructions: Apply advanced understanding of mass-volume stoichiometry.

sentences.text: When calculating greenhouse gas volumes, use the mole ratio to find moles of {{d1}}, then multiply by the molar volume at {{d2}} to get volume.

d1.tooltip: CO₂ or H₂O vapour from combustion

sentences.text: The volume of CO₂ from burning 1 kg of methane is much {{d3}} than 1 kg because CO₂ has a {{d4}} molar mass than CH₄.
Net greenhouse gas emissions consider that biofuels release CO₂ that was {{d5}} absorbed from the atmosphere, while fossil fuels release {{d6}} stored carbon.

d6.tooltip: Fossil fuels formed millions of years ago

sentences.text: A mass-volume calculation for octane combustion: 114 g octane → {{d7}} mol → {{d8}} mol CO₂ → volume at SLC.

d8.tooltip: C₈H₁₈ coefficient is 2, CO₂ is 16, so 1:8 ratio

volume_volume.title: Advanced Volume-Volume Applications
volume_volume.instructions: Apply advanced understanding of volume-volume stoichiometry.

sentences.text: A key advantage of volume-volume calculations is that you don't need to know the {{d1}} of the gases, only their {{d2}} in the equation.

d1.tooltip: Mass isn't needed for V:V ratios

d2.tooltip: The numbers give the volume ratio

sentences.text: When water forms as a liquid instead of gas, the volume-volume ratio for water {{d3}} be used, but it still applies for {{d4}} products.

d3.tooltip: Liquids don't follow gas volume ratios

sentences.text: If 100 L of methane burns in a closed container at constant T and P, the total volume of gaseous products is {{d5}} L, because CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O gives a ratio of {{d6}}.
Volume-volume stoichiometry works because at constant T and P, volume is directly proportional to {{d7}}, as stated by {{d8}} law.

d7.tooltip: V ∝ n at constant T and P

stoichiometry_definition.title: What is Stoichiometry?
stoichiometry_definition.content: Stoichiometry is the calculation of quantities in chemical reactions based on the mole ratios from balanced equations. It allows us to predict how much product will form from given reactants, or how much reactant is needed to make a certain amount of product.
keyPoints: Based on mole ratios from balanced equation coefficients
Allows prediction of amounts of reactants and products
Central unit is always moles
Can be extended to calculate mass, volume, or energy

mole_ratio.title: Using Mole Ratios
mole_ratio.content: The coefficients in a balanced equation give the mole ratios between all species. For example, in CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O, the ratios are 1:2:1:2. This means 1 mole of methane reacts with 2 moles of oxygen to produce 1 mole of CO₂ and 2 moles of water.
keyPoints: Coefficients give mole ratios, not mass ratios
Apply ratios by multiplying: if ratio is 1:3, multiply moles by 3
Works for any pair of species in the equation
Must convert mass or volume to moles first

slc_conditions.title: Standard Laboratory Conditions (SLC)
slc_conditions.content: SLC are the standard conditions used in VCE Chemistry: 25°C (298 K) and 100 kPa. At these conditions, the molar volume of any ideal gas is 24.8 L mol⁻¹. This is different from STP (0°C, 101.3 kPa) where the molar volume is 22.4 L mol⁻¹.
keyPoints: SLC: 25°C and 100 kPa (IUPAC standard)
Molar volume at SLC = 24.8 L mol⁻¹
STP: 0°C and 101.3 kPa (older standard)
Always use SLC values for VCE Chemistry

molar_volume.title: Molar Volume of Gases
molar_volume.content: Molar volume (Vm) is the volume occupied by one mole of gas at specified conditions. At SLC, Vm = 24.8 L mol⁻¹ for all ideal gases. This is based on Avogadro's law: equal volumes of gases at the same temperature and pressure contain equal numbers of molecules.
molar_volume.formula: n = V/Vm or V = n × Vm where Vm = 24.8 L mol⁻¹ at SLC
keyPoints: Same for all ideal gases at same conditions
24.8 L mol⁻¹ at SLC (25°C, 100 kPa)
22.4 L mol⁻¹ at STP (0°C, 101.3 kPa)
Allows conversion between moles and volume for gases

mass_to_moles.title: Converting Between Mass and Moles
mass_to_moles.content: The relationship between mass and moles uses molar mass (M): n = m/M. This formula can be rearranged to m = n × M or M = m/n. Always check units: mass in grams, molar mass in g mol⁻¹, moles in mol.
mass_to_moles.formula: n = m/M, m = n × M, M = m/n
keyPoints: n = m/M converts mass to moles
m = n × M converts moles to mass
Molar mass from periodic table (sum of atomic masses)
Units: g ÷ (g/mol) = mol

moles_to_volume.title: Converting Between Moles and Volume
moles_to_volume.content: For gases at SLC, use the molar volume to convert between moles and volume: V = n × Vm or n = V/Vm. At SLC, Vm = 24.8 L mol⁻¹. Ensure volume is in litres (not mL) when using this formula.
moles_to_volume.formula: V = n × Vm = n × 24.8 L (at SLC)
keyPoints: Only applies to gases
V = n × 24.8 gives volume in litres at SLC
n = V/24.8 gives moles from volume at SLC
Convert mL to L before using formula

mass_mass_process.title: Mass-Mass Stoichiometry
mass_mass_process.content: Mass-mass stoichiometry follows three steps: (1) convert known mass to moles using n = m/M, (2) apply the mole ratio from the balanced equation, (3) convert unknown moles to mass using m = n × M. This is often called the 'down, across, up' method.
keyPoints: Step 1: mass → moles (divide by molar mass)
Step 2: apply coefficient ratio
Step 3: moles → mass (multiply by molar mass)
Cannot skip the moles step

mass_volume_process.title: Mass-Volume Stoichiometry
mass_volume_process.content: Mass-volume stoichiometry connects mass of one substance to volume of a gas. The process is: convert mass to moles, apply the stoichiometric ratio, then convert moles to volume using V = n × Vm. Works in reverse for volume to mass.
keyPoints: Links solid/liquid mass to gas volume
Use n = m/M for mass-to-moles step
Use V = n × Vm for moles-to-volume step
At SLC, Vm = 24.8 L mol⁻¹

volume_volume_conditions.title: Conditions for Volume-Volume Stoichiometry
volume_volume_conditions.content: Volume-volume stoichiometry only works when specific conditions are met: all substances must be gases, temperature must be constant, pressure must be constant, and the system must be closed. Under these conditions, volume ratios equal mole ratios.
keyPoints: All species must be gases
Constant temperature required
Constant pressure required
Closed system (no gas escapes)

volume_volume_shortcut.title: Volume-Volume Direct Ratio Method
volume_volume_shortcut.content: When all conditions are met, the coefficients in a balanced equation directly give volume ratios for gases. No conversion to moles is needed. For example, if CH₄:CO₂ = 1:1 in the equation, then 5 L CH₄ produces 5 L CO₂.
keyPoints: Coefficients = volume ratios for gases
No need to convert to moles
Fastest stoichiometry method
Based on Avogadro's law: V ∝ n at constant T, P

greenhouse_gases.title: Greenhouse Gas Products from Combustion
greenhouse_gases.content: Combustion of hydrocarbon fuels produces CO₂ and H₂O, both greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming by absorbing infrared radiation. Stoichiometry allows calculation of the mass or volume of these gases produced from burning a given amount of fuel.
keyPoints: CO₂ and H₂O are greenhouse gas products
Complete combustion: CₓHᵧ + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O
Incomplete combustion also produces CO
CH₄ is itself a powerful greenhouse gas

limiting_reactant.title: Identifying the Limiting Reactant
limiting_reactant.content: When amounts of multiple reactants are given, the limiting reactant determines how much product forms. To identify it, divide each reactant's moles by its coefficient in the equation. The smallest result indicates the limiting reactant.
keyPoints: Limiting reactant is consumed first
Determines maximum product amount
Compare moles/coefficient for each reactant
Smallest ratio = limiting reactant

energy_from_stoichiometry.title: Connecting Stoichiometry to Energy
energy_from_stoichiometry.content: Stoichiometry can be used to calculate energy released in combustion. First find the moles of fuel burned, then multiply by the molar enthalpy of combustion (ΔH in kJ mol⁻¹). Energy = n × ΔH.
keyPoints: First calculate moles of fuel
ΔH is energy per mole (kJ mol⁻¹)
Energy = moles × ΔH
Negative ΔH indicates exothermic reaction
